metadata.sermon_start_end: The man who doubts the integrity of all other men is likely to say that every man has his price, meaning of course that a person's loyalty or love or support can be bought. Such a verdict puts a person's soul, his essential honor and character and being [...] What will a man give in exchange for his soul? There is nothing except God that is worth all that we are.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon uses the text as a thematic springboard rather than a specific pericope. It treats the verse as a 'biblical idea' or 'keyword' (the soul) which Dekker explicitly warns against. It fails to identify what is unique to this specific passage that cannot be found elsewhere.
quotes: For what is a man profited, if he shall gain the whole world, and lose his own soul?
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: The preacher must move beyond the general concept of 'the soul' and engage with the specific context of Matthew 16—the following of Christ and the taking up of the cross—which is entirely absent here.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is no evidence of linguistic or historical-critical engagement. The original context of Jesus speaking to his disciples about his impending suffering and the cost of discipleship is ignored in favor of a philosophical discussion on human value.
quotes: What is a human soul? How do we measure its worth? A human soul is the totality of our personhood.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Incorporate the Greek meaning of 'psyche' (life/soul) in the context of the synoptic gospels and explain how this text functioned for the first-century audience facing persecution.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is somewhat concrete regarding the 'zeitgeist' (nuclear anxiety, consumerism), but it remains largely in the realm of general truths and moralizing about 'baubles and prizes'. It lacks the specific 'spiritual life of the congregation' Dekker demands.
quotes: The rocket juggling and missile waving going on in our world cast a long dark shadow over the future of the earth.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Move from global anxieties (nuclear war) to the specific ways the local congregation is 'selling' its soul in daily ethical and social choices.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: Because there is almost no exposition, there is little to interweave. The sermon is a series of reflections on a theme rather than a movement where the hearer is 'expounded' alongside the text.
quotes: I submit to you in the light of this that too many of us sell our souls too cheaply.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Use the text's own logic (gain vs. loss) to structure the contemporary application, rather than imposing an external 'auction block' metaphor.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The sermon touches on misery (the 'ugly doomed world') and redemption (Christ as 'hiding place'), but the categories are more psychological/existential than dogmatic. The 'misery' is more about the world's decay than man's sin before God.
quotes: ...an instinct toward righteousness underneath our proneness to evil and wrong...
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Sharpen the definition of 'misery' as man's condition before God, rather than just the 'nervous disorder' of the world.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: This is the strongest point. The sermon takes the possibility of being 'lost' seriously, both temporally and eternally. It challenges the hearer's 'neutrality' and demands a choice.
quotes: No one can assume neutrality in the real or the physical world... The question is rather by whom or what [our souls are claimed].
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Connect the 'two ways' more clearly to the specific call of Christ in the text rather than a general 'destiny' of the soul.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is mentioned as the 'telos' at the end, but he appears more as a 'shelter' from a grim world than the incarnate God of the two-natures doctrine. Grace is present but feels like a safety net for the soul's value.
quotes: I know of no shelter except Jesus Christ. He is the only hiding place from the tempest...
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Explicitly ground the value of the soul in Christ’s redemptive work (the 'one Lord') rather than the soul’s inherent 'eternal' quality.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 1,150 words, the sermon would last roughly 11-12 minutes. This fails Dekker's absolute requirement of 20 minutes for 'depth'.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the exegetical foundation and the complexity of the application to reach the 20-minute threshold.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker's criteria primarily due to its lack of specific exegesis and its insufficient length. It treats the Bible passage as a thematic hook for a philosophical/psychological discourse on human worth rather than an exposition of the Word of God. While it effectively addresses the 'two ways' and the seriousness of human choice, it leans too heavily on the inherent value of the soul rather than the specific revelation of Christ in the text.
strengths: Strong emphasis on the 'two ways' and the impossibility of neutrality in spiritual life.
Effective identification of the 'zeitgeist' regarding nuclear anxiety and consumerist decay.
weaknesses: Critically short duration (approx. 11 minutes), lacking the 'breadth' required for depth.
Total absence of original context, Greek/Hebrew engagement, or historical exegesis.
Theological anthropocentrism: focusing on the soul's 'essential likeness to God' rather than the specific call to discipleship in Matthew 16.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is not a sermon in the sense of Dekker's definition. It is a thematic speech about 'the soul' and 'human value' that uses a biblical verse as an ornament. It lacks the formal requirements of exposition and the substantive requirement of duration.
